WRITING.TEXT: Prosecuting dead people is the very definition of wasting resources. The DOJ already gets stretched thin going after living criminals, no point in having them (or worse, a whole separate agency) going after people who by definition can't be brought to justice, just because it makes some people feel good. Historians can clear up the record without needing a government stamp of approval or government resources too.
The worst they'll get her on is perjury, and even that's pretty doubtful at this point if they're just going off her interview.

It's a bad thing because it is a waste of resources. Other than potentially going after this woman for perjury, which would be difficult if not impossible, there is no judicial route to seek justice for Emmet Till left. Everyone else involved is dead, so this would just take away resources from cases with potential real outcomes such as convictions or acquittals of living people.

You may not care if they're already dead, but the justice system should. You can't send a dead body to jail and there is no lack of actual living criminals that deserve their day in court and a proper prosecution. You're forgetting, or willfully ignoring, the fact that even the DOJ doesn't have limitless manpower, time, and resources.

Except here in the real world, where the DOJ has limited resources to prosecute cases, spending time and money on a case like this literally does take away resources that could be better used on actually prosecutable cases.

See the note at the bottom of the page. The author took some pictures themselves, but the restaurant forced them to use press photos, rather than allowing them to photograph the dish themselves (after the review was written, TIL that's a thing) to get more honest photos.
Some readers may notice a difference between my description of the onion dish mostly black, like nightmares and the picture of it above, which is golden and rather beautiful.
Theres a reason for this.
Le Cinq would not let us photograph their food, as we usually do after Ive reviewed, and insisted that we use press shots. This is extremely unusual. However, I did take pictures during the meal, on an iPhone 7 using the available light. And that makes things a little clearer, as you can see.
See also the first comment (marked "Guardian pick" which links [to an explanation](http://www.jayrayner.co.uk/news/spot-the-difference-the-food-pics-supplied-to-the-observer-by-le-cinq-in-paris-as-against-mine).

It's because BLM and other modern movements are inherently a bit insecure. Being leaderless, and to an extent rudderless, movements, they can much more easily be trivialized, marginalized, and just plain laughed off, not to mention potentially co-opted, than a movement with leaders that can better and more easily push back against any attempt to co-opt or marginalize the movement.

if the cost to employ someone would bankrupt the company, you don't hire that person
That's a bit of an extreme example, but in a less extreme example of just costing the company a lot of money, there is definitely a principle of hiring a person regardless of whether they're controversial or not. I'm not by any means saying it's the case here, but sometimes the most controversial candidate may be the best candidate (again, not the case here). That doesn't mean they should be excluded because of possible protests or violence though, since that is akin to appeasement, such as giving in to terrorism or other forms of violence. It's a form of surrender.

It's possible, but considering the amount volume of protests aimed towards her, it is pretty unlikely. I'm not sure Occam's razor applies here, since her having previous enemies (although those are weaker ties to security risks for her than her present job IMO) doesn't require more assumptions, but the simplest and IMO the most plausible one involves rowdy protesters who have no problem blocking her from doing her job.

It's possible, but considering the amount volume of protests aimed towards her, it is pretty likely that current security concerns are pretty heavily, if not entirely, necessitated by her present job. An FOIA request would be the only way to get a definitive answer though.

As utterly ridiculous as this is, her personal wealth and her family are entirely irrelevant. If the reasons for her needing protection are because of her job, then it is really the duty her employer, the US government, to pay to keep her safe. If it was a personal thing totally unrelated to her job, then that would be different, but that isn't the case here.

Pretty misleading title. Very little of it has to do with Uber, most of it is just an indictment of the fact that the US doesn't subsidize (or force companies to subsidize) pregnancy like other countries do. The parts that do have to do with Uber really apply to many part time/gig jobs right now. Not for nothing too, this article also lays out a long string of poor choices this woman made to get into this position, not even including getting pregnant with some deadbeat who can't help pay for it, that got her into this situation.
I'm not sure I agree with all the conclusions of this piece, but I think it definitely adds to the commonly brought up discussion of what the purpose of a business is and who is supposed to benefit.

I'd argue that it matters, if only because it was such a widespread and intergenerational shunning of something that had such a huge impact. Nobody is going to call *The Social Network* the greatest movie of all time (or even a great movie at that). They might not even call it a good movie. The same can't be said for Kane. Also, the timing is different. Zuckerberg could ban all references to the movie from Facebook, but it wouldn't have nearly the impact that Hearst blacklisting the film had. Also, unlike Hearst with *Citizen Kane*, it's a lot less likely that this will become an intergenerational thing.

Since when has BLM been high stakes? Police violence and the fact that it occurs in a relatively high percentage to minorities as a percentage of police violence and a percentage of police interactions is a problem, definitely, even a problem to be protested. Considering the fact that it is still tiny compared to every other rate of violence out there though (spousal/partner, other domestic, gang, road rage, sexual, etc...), calling it high stakes is just unsupportably hyperbolic.

That's a human nature problem then, not really a governance/government problem. The government shouldn't, in most cases, intervene because workers are too stupid and/or easily misled to accept useless promises and non-monetary rewards in return for ideas that could potentially yield a bonus, raise, or promotion. Companies aren't stealing from their employees from willingly extracting ideas from them.

That naturally discourages ideas from the bottom though. Nothing is stopping a worker from coming up with an idea but not telling their employer. They probably can't tell anyone else, because of IP restrictions and especially if created on company time, but they donut have to tell the company. Companies that value innovation from their employees will reward it accordingly and those that don't won't, and will get fewer ideas as a result. It's not a right vs wrong thing, it's just a company's culture and management.

If it's just replacing the prior test and isn't going to any effect on who's going to get a CT and when then I can definitely see the advantage, but I am, and I tend to think everyone should be, skeptical of that.

One would hope, but that still might delay treatment. In practice, it wouldn't, but experience, along with quite a few news stories and lawsuits, shows that given an excuse to not treat until test results come in, many doctors will do just that. So a test like this might not do more harm than the status quo, and might even do some good, but that's mitigated by the human factor.

It is, and yet, this is a man who wants to rebuild the Soviet empire and has no qualms about imprisoning of murdering anyone who gets in his way, not to mention eliminating any semblance of a free press. To wit, it's heinous, but not undeserved. On an individual level maybe they deserve sympathy, but most people don't know them as individuals. On a collective level though, they are props to make Putin look like a strong leader and, if this really is a false flag, discredit whichever group he chooses to. Even if this was a real attack, they're still props to be exploited, even beyond the extent that every country tries to capitalize on sympathy after terrorist attacks.

Not really, but my country stopped trying to invade its neighbors over a hundred years ago. Also, before you bring up the comparison to Tibet (I cheated and peeked at your history), that is even even worse IMO than Russia and Ukraine. My concern with Russia, and particularly Putin is much larger than Ukraine though. My concern is that he, and what at least seems like a large group of people in Russia and scattered throughout its former satellites, wants to recreate the Societ Union. There is an obsession, for lack of a better word, with bringing back the power and perceived respect that they had back then. That is rightfully scary to its neighbors who don't want to be under Russia's influence/control and to NATO, which does not want to deal with another Soviet regime gobbling up its neighbors.
What's the over/under on this being a false flag by Putin? When that Russian dictator allows free and open coverage of incidents like this, they'll be eligible for sympathy. Until then, Nyet!
Isn't that good for them though? If even they can see that he's an idiot, that's worrying, but they should be praising him for making their "jobs" easier.

Considering the relatively high probability, compared to other incidents like this, that this was a false flag, I'll hold my sympathy until we can get some sort of independent investigation. Since Russia has no independent media and is run by dictator, that's not going ot happen, so drinking vodka is the closest I'll get to sympathizing with them.

On one hand, there is a very real goal/standard in many cultures that lighter skin is better, and even though that standard has very real negative effects, companies have to (to an extent) follow what people want to buy. On the other hand, it is relevant how much do these companies help perpetuate and reinforce these negative cultural biases with advertising like this. Skin care companies especially, are often caught between a rock and a hard space. On the one hand, they can't be expected to forego sales by not marketing to, or outright ignoring what a large segment of the market is looking for. On the other hand, how many dark skinned people, even in relatively progressive countries like England are using lightening products but might not if they had a harder time identifying and/or buying products like that.

I'll assume that's aimed at me. Do you have any better analysis smart-ass? I'm getting downvoted to hell by idiots who value feelings over reality, but the truth is that unless they have a big secret (like collusion between the benefits managers and Mylan) up their sleeve, this looks like an incredibly weak case.
Also, if you want good proof that a lot of the feelz before realz people here are idiots, look at how many of them are saying that this will force the company to lower prices. Even in a scenario where they lose and have to pay every cent that they made back, there is no conceivable outcome in which the court sets the price that Mylan can charge.
The law is for allowing the government to set prices to a "reasonable" (purely subjective) level? Source?

America != Europe, or heavily European inspired countries like Canada. Unlike many other countries, we have a very different history that is based in large part on not letting the government run things unless there is a good reason to. Add a large dash of individuality, and it's a tough thing to overcome to make the case that the government should be running all health insurance.
If that wasn't enough, even though there would be very real advantages to government run health insurance, the idea of letting the government fund R D for drugs and medical technologies and then own a piece, if not all of the result has major problems, not least of which is how to still incentivize private money in the process (which would still be a necessity) while controlling prices and allowing/incentivizing multiple companies to compete on formulations and other relevant designs.

they introduced a substantial hike on a product with no competitor which literally saves lives
To play devil's advocate, the former isn't something they'll ever see as their problem, despite the fact that they've lobbied for that monopoly, and the latter is not something they ever need or want to concern themselves with. Saving lives is nice for PR, I'm sure, but they aren't in the job of saving lives, they're in the job of selling a product. If that product saves lives, then that's just the same as the result of anything else they sell.
Price gouging is, outside of specific laws ~~designed to limit supply of essentials during an emergency~~...wait that's not right...~~designed encourage hoarding~~~...wait, not that either...designed to control the price that people can sell products for during an emergency, is a purely subjective term. Without getting too much into moral relativism, there is no way to substantiate what is and isn't price gouging for a product with a steady demand, such as essential medications. They can and will pay what the market will bear, but barring outside influences (such as new government rules), that isn't going to change a whole lot. That actually supports the idea that they were, on a purely economic level, undercharging for their product, since they could have been charging the higher price for much longer.

It is a (potential) class action lawsuit, so they is a bunch of opportunist lawyers who have no real disincentive to trying everything and seeing what sticks. If the lawyers can get one accusation to stick then they look to get 30%+ of whatever damages they can get, or whatever settlement they can get, so of course they'll try racketeering if there is even a chance in hell of it working. That doesn't mean it will though or that it even has a real chance.

If absolutely is, but we get to enjoy being blindly downvoted for saying it like it is by the people here who don't care and think the laws should be just about "social justice."

Is there any reason to think that it will though? As far as I can tell (IANAL btw), the action is being brought because they are paying rebates to PBMs. If other companies are paying rebates as well, which seems likely, and Mylan is just paying higher than the competition, which the article implies, then Mylan will probably will win unless they're doing something else like colluding with the PBMs. Both the company and the PBMs wanting to make a profit, is not the same, and that statement as a reason to say that it is unfair, should be treated like a joke. I say good luck to the plaintiffs though if that's the tact they want to take.

Depends. If someone is allowed to do something but a large enough group of people think they are getting away with or have gotten away with it, does that justify going after them for something else? Mylan's price hikes were in themselves perfectly legitimate (i.e. allowed by laws and regulations). If other companies don't use these rebates like this then it may be a legitimate issue, but this smacks of revenge for the price increase, pure and simple. You can call that justified if you want, but it's a stretch to call it justice since it won't make them lower the price.
No, it's really not. Nice try at fallacious reasoning though.

Setting a price for a product that consumers or their surrogates (in this case insurance companies) are willing to pay isn't a crime though. As much as the social justice warriors here, and that wrote the article, would like it to be, this isn't at least directly about the high prices charged specifically because they are entitled to charge that price.

IANAL but no way in hell racketeering actually works though, unless collusion can be proven between Mylan and the PBMs, beyond the article's assertion that they both (shockingly /s) wanted to make a profit.

Why would they? Their point of view, sensibly from their position, is that they have a product and they have potential buyers, so why shouldn't they get the buyers to pay the most possible for the product. I'm sure that they're happy that patent laws and the whole insurance/PBM structure helps them get more money, but at the end of the day, they're charging, and are going to charge, what makes them the most for each unit.

Yeah, good luck to the plaintiffs if their only strategy is to claim that both Mylar and the PBMs wanted to make money. Everybody, and every company, wants to make money. Unless they can prove some sort of collusion between the company and the PBMs, they're going to be SOL. IANAL and even I can see that clear as day.
Edit: stupid autocorrect

That seemed unclear. From my understanding, every drug company uses rebates. The article gives a solid free market reason why they've succeeded where other companies failed, which is that the other companies couldn't/wouldn't compete on rebates. If rebates are accepted practice, as it seems they are, and there is nothing beyond them using them more heavily than the competition, as the article seems to heavily imply, then there is nothing there to go after.

The article is pretty heavily going after the company without explaining any actionable reason. People not liking the price or not being able to afford the product isn't in itself, a reason that action can be taken on. That is unless you want the government to be in the business of outright fixing prices (a la Venezuela).

Your story is nice and all, but neither Mylan nor any other company, has any duty to sell you medicine, lifesaving or otherwise, at an "affordable price" (in quotes because what that means is quite arguable).
These are for profit enterprises, and as such they're going to sell it for the highest price they can get. The problem comes when there is a government granted restriction who can sell (beyond necessary restrictions for safety, reasonable licensing, etc...) that creates a mon/duopoly.

I get the social justice argument, but there is no logical excuse to go after the company for **legally** raising its prices. Unless they were doing something fraudulent with the rebates, this will probably get thrown out since there is no law saying they can't raise their prices at will (nor should there be...government price controls are bad, mmmkay). The place where pressure should be placed is on Congress and the FDA to reform the system so that more competition can exist.
I don't think that means what you think that means. Look up thieving (or alternatively, theft) in the dictionary.
